column1: Before 1 October 2022, will Facebook announce that Mark Zuckerberg will cease to be the company's sole Chairman or CEO?
column6: ['Business', 'Leader Entry/Exit']
too powerful a man who has built it from the ground up... would cause more panic with the stock and company... however name change and news about him does increase the odds very very slightly.
It's not going to happen in one day. Also, he just made a prominent statement about "slashing head count" and I do not think he would have that authority if he was on the way out in 1 day.

Even there has always been some problems with Mark Zuckerberg I think his control and the way he advances Facebook he will not cease to be ceo or the sole ceo. People respect the progress he has made with the company and it will be a while till he ever ceases to be the ceo.

I'm late to responding to this question. But even so, I think Zuckerberg will continue to lead Facebook/Meta for years to come. That includes both as CEO and Chairman. I don't know much about Zuckerberg, but from what I've read/heard, he strikes me as the type of person who would not want to share power - i.e., I don't see him wanting to have some sort of co-CEO or co-Chairman. There has to be one decision maker and that's Zuckerberg, of course.
https://www.benzinga.com/general/entrepreneurship/22/09/28907714/this-harvard-expert-says-zuckerberg-continuing-to-derail-facebook-says-hes-really-lost-h

Zuckerberg is on, at the least, good terms with the company with a lack of controversy surrounding his position. Especially given radical shifts that the company thought of as good towards the Metaverse, Zuckerburg seems to be able to hold the position for the next while. In addition, the process of deposing a chair is lengthy, and with the time left, it is certain that Zuckerburg will not lose that position.
As of recently, Zuckerberg's net worth has plummeted by $76.8 billion since Sept 2021. He also owns 54% of voting rights in Meta, so it is unlikely he will drop his position.

I highly doubt this, considering October 1st is only a few days away and there has been no known movement inside the company pointing towards his departure. I understand the reasoning behind it, even just this month Zuckerberg has come under intense scrutiny for his leadership skills in an article published by CNBC after Meta had a 232 billion dollar drop in the stock market this February, the largest in US history. However, Zuckerberg's job seems relatively stable for the next few months and possibly years, but it has become clear his time leading his company may be coming to a close.
Nope

Mark Zuckerberg has been the primary figurehead of Facebook for a very long time. Facebook is still a massive corporation and despite the scrutiny on their business practices, I doubt it will be enough to dispel the corporation's trust in Mark.

I don't think that Zuckerberg will step down as being the company's sole chairman or CEO. Since the company has made some changes like switching its name, I think it would be too soon for him to step down after making this change. Additionally, as a business leader I don't think he would want to step down because of issues/pressures that are being faced within the company. It wouldn't be good press for him to step down due to problems in the company, I think he would try to fix issues first before considering stepping down. I think he will step down eventually but not before October 1, 2022.
Final decision.
Zuckerberg is still very active in this company, and it would be quite a shock if he were to step down at this point.
not happening

There has been no movement or indication that Zuckerberg will leave the company or even change his role at all. The company is still going through a lot right now with the name change and various privacy allegations and I see no evidence that he will step down.

The chances of Mark Zuckerburg stepping down from CEO at Meta are very slim to none. I gave a 5% chance that this will occur. Mark Zuckerberg has had no intention of giving any indication of stepping down from Meta. Because he has given no sign or indication of ceasing control over Meta, I do not see much of a chance that he suddenly decides to step down before October 1st, 2022.
No happening.

While Zuckerburg has faced recent scrutiny, there is nothing outstanding to suggest that Zuckerburg will cease to be the company's sole Chairman/CEO. Zuckerburg has retained his position through substantial controversy and scrutiny over years, and I predict that he will almost certainly remain in this position in the given timeframe.

Mark Zuckerberg has given no indication that he has any plans to step down or lessen his role at Meta, despite consistent controversy over the past year. Given this, and the fact that Mark Zuckerberg has stated on multiple occasions in the past year, both personally and via a Facebook spokesperson, that he has no plans on stepping down from the company, I believe there is around a 2% chance he ceases to be Meta's sole CEO by October 1.
Cash burning behemoth of the future, ill-advised investments in the metaverse - Zuck zucks.
He will likely go in the next year and a half - matter of probability if he goes in the next 2 weeks
Quarterly earnings report happens after 1st October
Zuckerberg seems to have achieved a sustainable amount of work-life balance, and there's not much time left for this to happen. Less than 1%.
He has faced criticism for a while and nothing seems to change
its not happening
There have been no signs of this happening as of yet.
No signs of such a thing happening at this point.
With only six weeks to go, the chance It will happen is vanishingly small.
"Strike four: Facebook misses election misinfo in Brazil ads"

If there will be a near-term adjustment of leadership, it will be due to election outcomes attributed to FB not preventing disinformation. This is probably the only thing that could evict a liberal darling - but not before OCT 1. New COO is interesting - potential leadership material if he had any charisma which he may not. He actually could act as a settler for a while, keeping Mark insulated. If a co-CEO comes on, I suspect it is either to focus on the FB brand while Mark does Meta at large, or an international CEO is brought in to settle down international election interference claims.

He is far more likely to lose his position as chairman than as CEO. Most companies prefer separate chairmen and CEO's, and there is a growing movement among Meta shareholders to bring Meta in line with this convention. However, this convention has been put aside in recent years so long as it achieves high growth. Zuckerberg's Metaverse plan is fairly sound and if unhindered will generate high growth and ensure his position. But, if there are any more scandals around Meta or Zuckerberg himself, it would very likely lead to his replacement as chairman and possibly also as CEO. Also, if the release of Project Cambria is botched or the product receives lacklustre sales due to high pricing, then this could lead to his being replaced as Chairman.
Rounding down to zero at this point
Another bad quarter. Something has to change, but it won't be the CEO.
Another bad quarter. Massive stock value loss this year. Something has to change.....
"Mark Zuckerberg to face deposition over Cambridge Analytica" (22 July 2022)

At this time I still have a low probability of this happening during this time frame as Zuck has a lot of control over the company and the company has 43B! in cash and $0! in debt which any public company would want in a heartbeat.
Zuckerberg, Meta's chief executive, has restructured his company so that he no longer has a top deputy.

Median CEO tenure is 5 years but "19 percent of all CEOs remain in position for 10 or more years, consistently, over the time period analyzed." (https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/news-room/press-releases/2019/ceo-turnover-record-high.html)

repeating previous forecast
Adjusting forecast for passage of time. The chances now seem vanishingly small.
With the musk Twitter acquisition the heat will be off Zuckerberg. If he is out of the news cycle the pressure will be diminished.

Can’t see this happening for years. What would be conditions for this to happen? Some kind of catastrophic devaluation caused by Zuckerberg himself or some internal nasty story, as opposed to market forces. Some scandal involving Zuckerberg. Zuckerberg wanting to free his time up for some other project. Or Elon Musk succeeding in buying Meta rather, or as well as Twitter. All these seem very unlikely.
What would make me increase my forecast? If meta’s market cap dropped yet another $100bn? No, probably not even that. Only a sudden and debilitating health crisis perhaps.
And why on earth did Zuck allow Sandberg to get company matter coalesced with private interest in such a disgusting way?
Why is Zuck talking so warmly of Sheryl Sandberg's "superpower"?
unlikely

As they have rebranded to Meta, Zuckerberg is technically is not the ceo of Facebook. Rather he is the ceo of meta.
Has Zuck been an "enabler" of the Russian Federation's pre-war propaganda for commercial interests?
With Zuck holding 58% of the voting shares of the company , there is no way he could be removed without his agreement. (Especially within the timeframe in question.)

I'm aware of the perils of substituting one question with another, but since Zuckerberg controls the majority of votes, I guess we can rephrase the question as "Before 1 October 2022, will Mark Zuckerberg announce that he will cease to be the company's sole Chairman or CEO?" Any rebuttal is welcome.
Revising down with stabilization of Meta stock.
Go with the flow.

Massive stock dip notwithstanding, Zuckerberg holds a controlling share of Meta’s voting stock and is untouchable. He only leaves when he decides it’s time; I doubt he entertains seriously the notion that his fortune is better off in the hands of a chosen successor, rather than his own.
Becoming difficult for the experts manage the various anti-Zuck factions on web, in print.
Traders/investors usually want to see heads rolling after such an amount of "blood in the streets".

"Shares of Facebook parent Meta Platforms plunged as much as 26% at today's open, the biggest-ever wipeout in market history" after first user base stagnation in the company’s history. Mark Zuckerberg's personal wealth potentially plummet about $24 billion https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-02-02/facebook-shares-plunge-as-users-stall-forecast-falls-short?srnd=premium
Increased prob. based on weak earnings / expected poor stock performance.
Adjusting forecast for passage of time.
Not likely barring sudden loss of profitability, personal scandal for Zuckerberg, etc.. Anti trust actions will be stuck in litigation for years.

Outside view (just taking a few peers): Alphabet - Page/Brin - CEO from 98->19, stepped down at age 47, length 32 years Microsoft - Gates - CEO from 72-08, stepped down age 52, length 37 years Amazon - Bezoes - CEO from 94-21, stepped down age 58, length 28 years Average length = 32 years, going to call this an annual prob of 1/32

Founder-CEOs in Silicon Valley have an average tenure of 14 years. If we use the IPO date as reference, Zuckerberg is CEO and chairman since 2012.

Maybe finally realizing that no one in Congress like him and a friendlier/older face might sweeten the regulatory environment I bet he shifts all in at Meta and someone else has to answer for facebook.
Doubling what I think the true chances are just because Meta is a new company and I think there are opportunities for expansion of what Facebook normally operated structurally.
He can take the company in the direction he wants far easier if he stays without other board members or another CEO
Clearly, he wants to use Facebook to make a new company.
He will move on to devote more time to technical vision and less time with legal hassles.

As I understand the arrangements at Facebook/Meta, he would have to agree to this He is not fond enough of reality to do that, and it is unlikely he'll die any time soon. Coming down another notch, but I'd love to be wrong.
He has become too controversial.
It doesn't seem likely he'll leave soon and it doesn't seem likely that there would be two or more CEOs or chairmen at one time.
Zuckerberg has increasingly made gafs but is still to powerful in the company, and profits are still holding up.

It is bad corporate governance to have the same individual as both Chair and CEO. I suspect investors will push Zuckerberg to relinquish one of these roles.

With the expansion of his vision to include Meta, I believe that the already extremely low probability decreased, as his founder vision for the Metaverse will now be his top priority -- aka he's not looking to cash in or share power, he's looking to essentially found his next company inside of his current one.

long way till resolution, still staying above the crowd, as the rodeo over social media and it's unaddressed (and easily addressable) negative impact on society stays IN THE NEWS with bipartisan support (if for different reasons nonetheless)

I’m really struggling to understand why people give this a 1 in 10 chance. Zuck has absolute dictatorial power over Facebook. Nobody can make him step down. He is young and has done nothing else with his life but run Facebook, he fashions himself as a 21st century Carnegie (if not Augustus). He’s not going anywhere.

Thought about this some more and I feel that I gave too much correlation between tech sector stocks tanking and MZ leaving. On top of that I think Meta has now 'weathered' it's recent storm (if you can all it that). That leaves a personal decision to leave (keeping that at 3% as there is still 10 months left on this), a lower chance of a Meta specified stock crash (1-2%) and then a tech sector stock crash, which I'm not sure would necessarily be correlated with getting rid of a CEO given that he has objectively run Facebook/Meta well for over a decade. I don't think investors will find a better choice for CEO in the allotted timeframe anyway.

I believe he would only do this under extreme pressure, and I can't see that on this horizon. The other shareholders have a minority stake (so can be ignored) and this Congress will fulminate but not act politically.

There is a real chance this happens. I don't think he wants to let go of the reigns, but he may have no choice depending on the stock price and any government action. Leaving may be the best thing for him and the company, and he can become a full time philanthropist.
because zuckerberg enjoys power, he is not going to give it away
Median of 6 of my predictions. Surprised how low it is given the "inside view" that Zuckerberg is under relatively frequent controversy as of late.
Anything can happen. But MZ isn't showing any signals of stepping down.

Adjusting for passage of time, and for the fact that the Frances Haugen stuff seems to be receding from public memory fast, with no apparent impact on share prices (they’re going up again). Apparently it will take even bigger disclosures to cause change.

As long as shares trade well and he is still young, he must not worry about his position. Yet Zuckerberg might take someone as a co- or vice- in order to share responsibility for failures and to keep the government at bay.
MZ having controlling voting power makes this very unlikely

I think there are a few scenarios where MZ will no longer be in charge alone: 1) Meta specific stock crash (<3% chance of this happening so soon, but highly likely he would leave in this case) 2) Tech sector stock crash (5-20% chance of this happening, medium correlation with this and him no longer being sole Chairman/CEO) 3) Personal decision (who knows, but he's been there since 2004 and there is no definitive sign he will necessarily go in the next ~20 years even. Likelihood of him dissappearing in any given year is quite low, although may be slightly elevated by the rebranding which gives an opportunity to leave without being too shocking - estimate this at 3%)
Continued bad news drip combined with emphasis on outside interests.
Zuckerberg has been described as the biggest drag on the Meta share price. He is widely disliked and he does not present well. I think to protect his fortune and reputation he will move aside.
I think it is closer than ever before, but who would take over?
has not shown any obvious signs.. challenges arising from the whistleblower testimony will not percolate through and effect change by then..

I don't completely understand the clarification. When the question was written, "Facebook" was a company and a website/social media platform. The company owned and ran the website. The *website* didn't have a Chairman or CEO; the *company* did. The same holds true now. Facebook, the company, changed its name to Meta. As before, Meta owns the Facebook website/social media platform. From Meta: "Our corporate structure is not changing, however, how we report on our financials will. Starting with our results for the fourth quarter of 2021, we plan to report on two operating segments: Family of Apps and Reality Labs." https://about.fb.com/news/2021/10/facebook-company-is-now-meta/ So "Facebook" doesn't have a Chairman or CEO right now; Meta does. And unless a new company is formed to run the Facebook website/social media platform, it will continue to be run by Meta. I am going to guess that that will continue to be how FB operates; I don't foresee Zuckerberg ever letting go voluntarily, especially for some riskier venture. And I can't picture some Family of Apps holding company being split off under Meta because his Reality Labs need cash from the Family of Apps, although it's possible that funds could just be channeled through Meta.

Considerations: Share price will dictate the decision to replace/not replace Mark Zuckerberg. The name change to META was a first step move but rebranding alone often doesn't work. Also, Mark Z has often mentioned that he would like to follow the path of other CEOs like Bezos, and Bill Gates.
holding
It's still to eearly.He doesn't want to handover the reigns before he is confident that Facebook is in a good place in terms of hate speech, echo chamber and similar.
If Meta flops
I have a sense of "fallout." Intuitive forecast.

Mark is young and Facebook is his baby. He's the visionary and has lead Facebook to be one of the most valuable companies in the world. While reputation is down right now, time passes and people forget. There would have to be several quarters of poor performance before I see Mark feeling the pressure to step down.

I foresee the potential need for a clarification. "The rebrand would likely position the blue Facebook app as one of many products under a parent company overseeing groups like Instagram, WhatsApp, Oculus, and more." https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/19/22735612/facebook-change-company-name-metaverse

If he is friends with Bezos who can counsel him on how to pull out gracefully, he might. If he is on his own, his ego will prevent him from stepping down and the board is generally powerless at this point.
staying above crowd
He is majority shareholder, so technically he would only do so at his own discretion - which he has not signalled at all;

While seemingly unlikely, the potential for (i) blowback from recent reports regarding FB burying Instagram impacts on teen mental health; and (ii) health / other personal issues / new ventures suggest the likelihood is low but not implausibly so.

He would have to voluntarily step down as there are not enough votes to remove him. Men in power rarely step down voluntarily. A young arrogant man is even less likely to step down. A massive employee revolt is probably the only thing that could get him to step down.

Imo, the only way he wouldn't be sole Chairman or CEO would be if he got too sick or died. Given that we're in a pandemic and that accidents can happen, I'll give it 1%. https://www.morningstar.com/articles/1061237/how-facebook-silences-its-investors
Holds preferential shares
Assuming only a further black swan event could force Mark Zuckerberg to relinquish full control.
Zuckerberg does not want to give up the power or share the power.

The problem lies in the fact that there are no consequences if Facebook doesn`t ensure that it is a "safe and positive place". Asking Facebook to self regulate and choose to do "what is right" over profits is rather impractical. Given that divisive content draws more eyeballs, I don't see any of the advertisers announcing that they will voluntarily not advertise on Facebook(This is the only thing that would have an impact on Facebook`s bottom-line).
It would be sweet, but who's foolish enough to take that job ?

Zuck is young and impossible to remove as CEO of the company he created; he would only leave voluntarily and this is extraordinarily unlikely, he views himself as a modern day Caesar. He will not abdicate.
After a helpful prod/comment by @ctsats and watching the early bets by others, I'll still happily stay above the crowd, but I'll ride closer.

Mr Z controls 58% of the shareholder vote. This is not the first Facebook controversy and he has never shown any signs of relinquishing control. The only reasons I can see this resolving to yes are: some as of now unknown catastrophe that makes shareholders start bailing (low probability) or Mr Z ceasing to exist (very low probability).

It seems to me that the trends of many men in power these days is to deny, never admit to anything and to double down on what they're doing when faced with criticism. Like Trump, they keep getting away with it all, so why stop?
No base rates available for this question.

"Under the current structure, Class A voters receive only one vote per share, while Class B voters—which consist of the company's management and directors—receive 10 votes per share. This means that Zuckerberg, the company's majority shareholder who holds 75% of Facebook's Class B stock, controls 58% of Facebook's vote. " https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2019/06/facebook-investors-revolt-against-mark-zuckerberg [June 4, 2019]
